[[File:Elwood Mead cph.3b30798.jpg|right|thumb|Elwood Mead in 1928]] '''Elwood Mead''' (January 16, 1858 – January 26, 1936) was a professor, [[politician]] and [[engineer]], known for heading the [[United States Bureau of Reclamation]] (USBR) from 1924 until his death in 1936. During his tenure, he oversaw some of the most complex projects the Bureau of Reclamation has undertaken. These included the [[Hoover Dam|Hoover]], [[Grand Coulee Dam|Grand Coulee]] and [[Owyhee Dam|Owyhee]] dams.
==Early life and career== Mead was born in [[Patriot, Indiana]], and graduated from [[Purdue]] with a [[Bachelor of Science]] in 1882. He worked for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in Indianapolis for seven months and departed for [[Fort Collins, Colorado]], by the end of the year.
There he started work as a professor by teaching mathematics at [[Colorado Agricultural College]] from 1883 until 1884, and again from 1886 to 1888. He developed and taught the first class on irrigation engineering in the United States. Mead also worked for the Colorado State Engineer's Office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usbr.gov/history/commiss.html|title=Commissioners of Reclamation|accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kluger|first1=James|title=Turning on Water with a Shovel: the career of Elwood Mead|date=1992|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|location=Albuquerque}}</ref>
==Public service== [[File:elwood-mead-2.jpg|thumb|right|Elwood Mead portrait]] In 1888, Mead became the territorial and state engineer of [[Wyoming]]. From 1888 until 1899, he was key in drafting the water laws for Wyoming. He was also a key supporter of the Cody Canal, one of the nation's first [[Carey Act]] projects undertaken by a group of investors, including [[Buffalo Bill|William F. Cody]].<ref name="Bonner">{{cite book | last = Bonner| first = Robert| title = William F. Cody's Wyoming empire: the Buffalo Bill nobody knows| publisher = University of Oklahoma Press| year = 2007|pages = 318| isbn = 978-0-8061-3829-9}}</ref>
In 1899, Mead was appointed head of irrigation investigations for the [[U.S. Department of Agriculture]], based out of Cheyenne. There he had an important role of directing irrigation studies across the west.
In 1907, Mead was appointed Chairman of the State Rivers and Water Supply Commission of [[Victoria, Australia]]. He served there for four years, though the Australian records show that he continued to work there until May, 1915.
In 1911, he returned to the United States to become the professor of Rural Institutions, [[University of California]], and chairman of the [[California Land Settlement Board]]. His ideas about developing efficient rural communities would later influence what would become the [[Resettlement Administration]] communities of the [[New Deal]].
[[File:Elwood-mead.jpg|thumb|left|Elwood Mead]] He continued to serve in California until 1924, when he was appointed Chairman of the Bureau of Reclamation (USBR) by President [[Calvin Coolidge]]'s administration. In 1923 and again in 1927, he went to [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestine]] to help the [[Zionist]]s develop irrigation and development plans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.macam.ac.il/~arnon/Int-ME/water/AN%20AMERICAN%20IN%20PALESTINE.htm| title=AN AMERICAN IN PALESTINE: ELWOOD MEAD AND ZIONIST WATER RESOURCE PLANNING, 1923-1936| accessdate=December 4, 2005}}</ref> At the USBR, Mead oversaw the planning and execution of construction of major water control and irrigation projects in the West: the [[Hoover Dam|Hoover]], [[Grand Coulee Dam|Grand Coulee]] and [[Owyhee Dam|Owyhee]] dams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunsetcities.com/lake-mead/dr%20elwood%20mead.html|title=Dr. Elwood Mead Commissioner of Bureau of Reclamation 1924-1936 - Lake Mead NRA|accessdate=December 4, 2005}}</ref>
Mead died on January 26, 1936, at the age of 78 in Washington, D.C., from [[thrombosis]], just four months after the completion of Boulder Dam. Originally interred at [[Abbey Mausoleum (Arlington County, Virginia)|Abbey Mausoleum]], he was reburied at National Memorial Park in [[Falls Church, Virginia]], in 2001 after the former crypt closed and was demolished.
==Legacy and honors== [[Lake Mead]], formed by the construction of the [[Hoover Dam]] on the [[Colorado River]], was named after Mead.<ref>{{cite book | url=http://dwgateway.library.unr.edu/keck/histtopoNV/Origin_of_Place_Names_Files/1941NevadaOriginofNames-pt1.pdf | title=Origin of Place Names: Nevada | publisher=W.P.A. | author=Federal Writers' Project | year=1941 | pages=16}}</ref> He is also the namesake to the [[SS Elwood Mead|SS ''Elwood Mead'']], a [[Liberty ship]] which was launched in 1944.

'''Farmitalia''' was an Italian pharmaceutical company best known for its parallel discovery with [[Rhone-Poulenc]] of [[daunorubicin]] and subsequent discovery of [[doxorubicin]].<ref name="weiss">{{cite journal |author=Weiss RB |title=The anthracyclines: will we ever find a better doxorubicin? |journal=Seminars in Oncology |volume=19 |issue=6 |pages=670–86 |date=December 1992 |pmid=1462166}}</ref> Farmitalia had been founded in 1935 as a joint venture by [[Rhone-Poulenc]] and [[Montecatini (company)|Montecatini]].<ref name= Lombardia/>
In 1978 it was merged with '''Carlo Erba SpA''', a pharmaceutical company that had been founded in 1853 by the pharmacist Carlo Erba, in which Montecatini had acquired a controlling interest in 1971; the merged company was called Farmitalia Carlo Erba SpA.<ref name="Lombardia">{{cite web |last=Bilotto |first=Antonella |publisher=LombardiaBeniCulturali |url=http://www.lombardiabeniculturali.it/archivi/soggetti-produttori/ente/MIDB0017BE/ |title=Carlo Erba SpA |accessdate=9 May 2017}}</ref>
Farmitalia Carlo Erba was acquired by [[Pharmacia]] in 1993<ref>Staff. [http://annonc.oxfordjournals.org/content/4/5/345.2.extract News: Farmitalia bought by Kabi Pharmacia]. Ann Oncol (1993) 4 (5): 345.</ref> and Pharmacia was acquired by [[Pfizer]] in 2003.<ref>Staff, CNN/Money. April 16, 2003 [http://money.cnn.com/2003/04/16/news/companies/pfizer_pharma/ It's official: Pfizer buys Pharmacia ]</ref>
Drugs discovered at Farmitalia that reached the market included (with date of first publication): * 1960 [[Sulfalene]]<ref>Baruffa G. Clinical trials in Plasmodium falciparum malaria with a long-acting sulphonamide. Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg. 1966;60(2):222-4. {{PMID|5332105}} </ref><ref>Per prior citation, the first publication: Camerino B, Palamidessi G (1960) Derivati della parazina II. Sulfonamdopir (in Italian). Gazz Chim Ital 90:1802–1815</ref> * 1963 [[Daunorubicin]]<ref>Suarato A, Angelucci F, Geroni C. Ring-B modified anthracyclines. Curr Pharm Des. 1999 Mar;5(3):217-27. Review. {{PMID|10066891}}</ref><ref>Grein A, et al. Descrizione e classificazione di un attinomicete (Streptonryces peucetius sp. nova) produttore di una sostanza ad attivita antitumorale. Giorn. Microbiol. 11: 109~ 118, 1963 </ref> * 1969 [[Doxorubicin]]<ref name="weiss"/><ref name="pmid5365804">{{cite journal |vauthors=Arcamone F, Cassinelli G, Fantini G, etal |title=Adriamycin, 14-hydroxydaunomycin, a new antitumor antibiotic from ''S. peucetius'' var. ''caesius'' |journal=Biotechnol Bioeng |volume=11 |issue=6 |pages=1101–10 |year=1969 |pmid=5365804 |doi=10.1002/bit.260110607}}</ref> * 1980 [[Cabergoline]]<ref name=SuppProtec>[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/444169/o13295.pdf Council regulation (EEC) no 1768/92 in the matter of Application No SPC/GB94/012 for a Supplementary Protection Certificate in the name of Farmitalia Carlo Erba S. r. l.]</ref><ref>[http://worldwide.espacenet.com/searchResults?submitted=true&&DB=EPODOC&ST=advanced&TI=&AB=&PN=GB%202074566 Espace record: GB 202074566]</ref> * 1984 [[Reboxetine]]<ref>Cocchiara G, et al Comparison of the disposition and of the metabolic pattern of Reboxetine, a new antidepressant, in the rat, dog, monkey and man. Eur J Drug Metab Pharmacokinet. 1991 Jul-Sep;16(3):231-9. {{PMID|1814741}}</ref><ref>First publication per prior citation: Melloni M et al. Potential antidepressant agents. α-aryloxy-benzyl derivatives of ethanolamine and morpholine. Eur J Med Chem, 3 (1984), pp. 235–242</ref>

[[File:Halo-flood-forms-library.png|thumb|Protagonist [[Master Chief (Halo)|Master Chief]] (left) encounters the Flood in ''[[Halo: Combat Evolved]]'' (2001)]]
The '''Flood''' are fictional [[parasite|parasitic]] [[extraterrestrial life|alien]] life forms in the ''[[Halo (series)|Halo]]'' video game series created by [[Bungie]]. They are introduced in ''[[Halo: Combat Evolved]]'' as a second enemy faction alongside the [[Covenant (Halo)|Covenant]]; they return in later entries in the series such as ''[[Halo 2]]'', ''[[Halo 3]]'', and ''[[Halo Wars]]''. The Flood are driven by a desire to infect any sentient life they encounter, and are depicted as such a threat that the ancient [[Factions of Halo#Forerunners|Forerunners]] killed themselves and all other sentient life in the galaxy in an effort to stop the Flood.
The Flood's design and fiction was spearheaded by Bungie artist Robert McLees, who utilized unused concepts from the earlier Bungie game ''[[Marathon 2]]''. The setting of the first game, the ringworld [[Halo (megastructure)|Halo]], was stripped of many of its large creatures to make the Flood's appearance more startling. Bungie environment artist Vic DeLeon spent six months of pre-production time refining the Flood's fleshy aesthetic and designing the organic interiors of Flood-infested space ships for ''Halo 3''.
The player's discovery of the Flood in ''Halo: Combat Evolved'' is a major plot twist, and was one of the surprises reviewers noted positively upon release. The Flood's return in ''Halo 2'' and ''Halo 3'' was less enthusiastically praised. Reaction to the Flood has varied over the years; while some found the Flood too derivative and a cliché element of science fiction, some others ranked them among the greatest villains of all time.
==Development== [[Image:Flood concept.png|thumb|left|alt=Sketch of a humanoid alien. Tentacles sprout out where the head would be and long whiplike tentacles extend from the hand|Concept art of a Flood combat form. The left hand has been replaced with tentacles, and the infection form's sensory apparatus sprout out where the head once was before it was corrupted]] The Flood are depicted as parasitic organisms that infect any sentient life of sufficient size. The largest self-contained form that the Flood can produce itself without using other biomass is an "infection form".<ref>{{cite book |last= Trautmann|first=Eric|title=The Art of Halo|date= 2004|publisher= Del Ray Publishing|location=New York |isbn=0-345-47586-0 |page=64}}</ref> These forms seeks hosts living or dead, attempting to drive sharp spines into the host and tap into the nervous system. The host is incapacitated while the infection form burrows into the host's body and begins the mutation process, bringing the host under Flood control.<ref>Dietz (2003), p. 140.</ref> Depending on the size or condition of the body, the infection form mutates the hapless host into various specialized forms in the continual drive for more food. Larger hosts are seen turned into forms for combat, growing long whiplike tentacles,<ref name="piggy">{{cite book|title=Prima's Official Strategy Guide: Halo 2|pages=120–123|publisher=Random House|location=New York|date=2004|isbn=0-7615-4473-9}}</ref> while mangled and disused hosts are turned into incubators for more infection forms.<ref name="piggy"/> The Flood also create forms such as a central intelligence or "Gravemind" to drive the infestation.
The Flood were added early in the development of the 2001 video game ''[[Halo: Combat Evolved]]'', before the game had made its jump from the [[Apple Macintosh|Macintosh]] platform to the [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]]. A design for one Flood form appeared as early as 1997.<ref>{{cite book |last= Trautmann|first=Eric|title=The Art of Halo|date= 2004|publisher= Del Ray Publishing|location=New York |isbn=0-345-47586-0 |page=67}}</ref> Commenting upon the inception of the Flood, Bungie staff member Chris Butcher noted that "the idea behind the Flood as the forgotten peril that ended a galaxy-spanning empire is a pretty fundamental tenet of good sci-fi. Yeah, and bad sci-fi too."<ref>{{cite web|date=January 9, 2002|author=Butch, Chris |author2= |url=http://halo.bungie.org/misc/interviews/getinthegame.butcher.010902/|title=Halo Chat with Developer Chris Butcher|publisher=[[Halo.Bungie.Org]]|accessdate=September 3, 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140802081842/http://halo.bungie.org/misc/interviews/getinthegame.butcher.010902/|archivedate=August 2, 2014}}</ref> Another inspiration was [[Christopher Rowley]]'s ''The Vang'' series.<ref name="gamespot-halo">{{cite web|author=Staff|date=November 17, 2006|url=http://www.gamespot.com/xbox360/action/halo3/news.html?sid=6162009&mode=previews&msg_sort=1&cpage=11|title=Halo Q&A--Past, Present, Future|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=September 24, 2011}}</ref> The early design for the Flood was done by Bungie artist and writer Robert McLees, who considers himself "the architect" of the Flood;<ref>{{cite web|author= Smith, Luke|url= http://www.bungie.net/News/content.aspx?type=topnews&cid=12753|title= Halo Universe: Covenant Weapons|accessdate= November 9, 2007|publisher= [[Bungie]]|date= September 6, 2007|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071011163447/http://www.bungie.net/News/content.aspx?type=topnews&cid=12753|archivedate= October 11, 2007|df= mdy-all}}</ref> the Flood's roots are reflected in concept art of a "fungal zombie" that McLees did for the earlier Bungie game ''[[Marathon 2: Durandal]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author=McLees, Robert|url=http://www.bungie.net/projects/marathon/asset_popup_viewer.aspx?at=51&cc=33&item=2|title=Marathon Series Concept Art|accessdate=November 9, 2007|publisher=[[Bungie]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114162205/http://www.bungie.net/projects/marathon/asset_popup_viewer.aspx?at=51&cc=33&item=2|archivedate=November 14, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref> McLees also did all the early concept art for the Flood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bungie.net/perlbin/blam.pl?file=/site/0/news/stories/robt_mclees_interviewed_by_you.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030608213532/http://www.bungie.net/perlbin/blam.pl?file=%2Fsite%2F0%2Fnews%2Fstories%2Frobt_mclees_interviewed_by_you.html |archivedate=June 8, 2003 |accessdate=April 10, 2008 |title=Robert McLees Interviewed By You! |publisher=[[Bungie]] |date=February 13, 2002 |author=Bungie |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Based on the behavior of viruses and certain bacteria, the Flood were intended to be "disgusting and nasty".<ref name="deleon-flood"/> The creatures were constructed from the corpses and bodies of former combatants, so the artists had to make sure the Flood soldiers were recognizable while changing their silhouette enough to differentiate them from the uninfected.<ref name="art of halo 3"/> Many concepts and ideas were discarded due to time constraints—initially, the Flood were intended to convert any species of the alien [[Covenant (Halo)|Covenant]] into soldiers. "We didn't have the resources to make it happen," McLees recalled, so they modified the game's fiction to suggest that some Covenant were too small or too frail to be combat troops.<ref name="feast of bones">{{cite web|author=Osborne, Eric|date=March 29, 2010|url=http://www.bungie.net/News/content.aspx?type=topnews&link=Feast_of_Bones|title=Feast of Bones|publisher=[[Bungie]]|accessdate=March 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100331183009/http://www.bungie.net/News/content.aspx?type=topnews&link=Feast_of_Bones|archivedate=March 31, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Likewise, the Flood enemy intelligence was intended to be as complicated as that of the other enemy faction in the game, the Covenant, but full implementation was cut for time. The dinosaur-like terrestrial wildlife that originally dwelled in Halo's environments were dropped due to gameplay constraints and fear that their pretense would reduce the surprise and impact of the Flood.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bungie.net/News/TopStory.aspx?story=prexboxhistory040904 |title=One Million Years B.X. |date=February 10, 2006 |publisher=[[Bungie]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060210224125/http://www.bungie.net/News/TopStory.aspx?story=prexboxhistory040904 |archivedate=February 10, 2006 }}</ref>
Bungie decided a new visual language for the Flood was needed for ''Halo 3''. The task of developing the new Flood forms, organic Flood terrain, and other miscellaneous changes fell to Vic DeLeon, then Bungie's Senior Environment Artist.<ref name="deleon-flood">{{cite web|author=DeLeon, Vic |date=May 28, 2008 |url=http://www.bungie.net/Inside/publications.aspx |title=Bungie Publications: Halo 3 Flood Alien Level Autopsy |publisher=[[Bungie]] |accessdate=July 12, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203200020/http://www.bungie.net//images/Inside/publications/presentations/!Halo3_Flood_Alien_Level_Autopsy.zip |archivedate=February 3, 2009 |df= }}</ref> Early concepts of what became new Flood types in the game called "pure forms" featured the creatures wielding an array of weapons via tendrils, while forms like the Flood Infector and Flood Transport concepts never made it into the final game.<ref name="art of halo 3">{{cite book|author=Bungie|editor=Mario de Govia|date=2008|title=The Art of Halo 3|publisher=Random House|location=Roseville, California|isbn=978-0-7615-6072-2|pages=26–27}}</ref> Flood-infested structures were designed as angular to counterbalance Flood biomass, as well as provide surfaces for the game's artificial intelligence to exploit and move on. New additions were designed to be multi-purpose; exploding "growth pods" that spew Flood forms were added to the game to adjust pacing, provide instant action, and add to the visuals. [[Endoscopy|Endoscopic]] pictures provided further inspiration.<ref name="deleon-flood"/> ''Halo 3'' added new capabilities to the Flood, including the ability for the parasite to infect enemies in real time.<ref name="deleon-flood"/> Bungie used ''Halo 3''{{'}}s improved capacity for graphics to make a host's sudden transformation into Flood form more dramatic; two different character models and skeletons were fused and swapped in real-time.<ref>{{cite journal|author=McEachern, Martin|date=December 2007|title=Making Halo 3 Shine|journal=Computer Graphics World|volume=30|issue=12|pages=18–25}}</ref> <!-- halo wars --> ==Appearances== ===Main games=== The Flood make their first appearance more than halfway through ''Halo: Combat Evolved'', during the story mission "343 Guilty Spark". A group of humans fleeing the enemy aliens [[Factions of Halo#Covenant|Covenant]] land on "[[Halo (megastructure)|Halo]]", a [[ringworld]] built by the alien Forerunners. The human commander [[Characters of Halo#Jacob Keyes|Jacob Keyes]] disappears in a swamp while searching for a weapons cache. The artificial intelligence [[Cortana (Halo)|Cortana]] sends the supersoldier [[Master Chief (Halo)|Master Chief]] to find Keyes. The Master Chief discovers that the Covenant have accidentally released the Flood. Keyes' squad is turned into soldiers for the parasite, while Keyes is interrogated by the Flood in an attempt to learn the location of Earth and ultimately assimilated. The emergence of the Flood prompts Halo's caretaker artificial intelligence [[Characters of Halo#343 Guilty Spark|343 Guilty Spark]] to enlist the help of the Master Chief in activating Halo's defenses and preventing a Flood outbreak. When Master Chief learns that activating Halo would instead wipe the galaxy of sentient life to prevent the Flood's spread, he and Cortana instead detonates the human ship ''Pillar of Autumn''{{'}}s engines, destroying the ring and preventing the Flood from escaping.
The Flood return in ''[[Halo 2]]'' (2004), appearing on [[Halo (megastructure)#Installation 05|Installation 05]] or "Delta Halo". The Flood on Delta Halo are led by the [[Gravemind]], a massive Flood intelligence that dwells in the bowels of the ring. Gravemind brings together the Master Chief and [[Arbiter (Halo)|the Arbiter]] and tasks them with stopping the Covenant leadership from activating the ring. In the meantime, Gravemind infests the human ship ''In Amber Clad'' and crashes it into the Covenant space station of ''High Charity''. Once there, the Flood sweep through the city, and the Gravemind captures Cortana. As the Flood spread, the Covenant form a blockade in an effort to prevent the parasite from leaving its prison.<ref>{{cite book |last= Nylund|first= Eric|authorlink=Eric Nylund|title=[[Halo: First Strike]]|date= 2003|publisher= [[Ballantine Books]]|location=New York |isbn=0-345-46781-7|page=21}}</ref>
The Flood reappear in the ''[[Halo 3]]'' mission "Floodgate", on board a damaged ship that escapes the quarantine around Delta Halo. While the infestation of Earth is prevented, Master Chief and Arbiter form a tenuous alliance with the Flood to stop the activation of all the Halo rings at the Forerunner installation known as the Ark. Once the threat is stopped, the Gravemind turns on them. The Master Chief fights his way to the center of ''High Charity'', freeing Cortana and destroying the city, but Gravemind attempts to rebuild himself on a Halo under construction at the Ark. Realizing that activating the ring will destroy only the local Flood infestation due to the Ark's location outside of the Milky Way, the Master Chief, Arbiter, Cortana and Sergeant Johnson proceed to Halo's control room, activate the ring, and escape. However, the Gravemind warns them that his defeat will only delay the Flood, not stop it.
The Flood also make appearances in the video game spinoffs ''[[Halo Wars]]'' and ''[[Halo Wars 2]]''. In ''Halo Wars'', they are encountered infesting a Forerunner installation and ultimately annihilated by the actions of the crew of the humans ship ''Spirit of Fire''. In the ''Halo Wars 2'' expansion "Awakening the Nightmare", the alien faction known as the Banished accidentally release the Flood while salvaging the wreck of ''High Charity''.
===Other appearances=== The 2006 anthology ''[[The Halo Graphic Novel]]'' expands upon the Flood's release from Halo in two stories. The first, ''Last Voyage of the Infinite Succor'', takes place at the same time as the Master Chief hunts for Keyes during ''Halo: Combat Evolved''. The Flood manage to pilot a Covenant dropship off Halo, and infest a Covenant ship, ''Infinite Succor''. The Flood are stopped by a Covenant strike team led by [[Characters of Halo#Rtas 'Vadum|Rtas 'Vadumee]], who sets the ship on a course into the nearby sun.<ref name="Hammock 2006">{{cite book |last= Hammock|first= Lee|title=The Last Voyage of the Infinite Succor|date= 2006|publisher= Marvel Comics|isbn=0-7851-2372-5 |pages=}}</ref> The second story, ''Breaking Quarantine'', details the escape of Sergeant [[Characters of Halo#Avery Johnson|Avery Johnson]] from the clutches of the Flood, immediately after Keyes' squad is overrun. Whereas the Flood are only hinted at being intelligent in ''Halo: Combat Evolved'', the ''Halo Graphic Novel'' shows the Flood have a [[group mind (science fiction)|hive mind]], assimilating the knowledge of their hosts rapidly. [[Lee Hammock]], writer of ''The Last Voyage of the Infinite Succor'', described the basis of the story as a way to showcase the true danger of the Flood as an intelligent menace, rather than something the player encounters and shoots. Hammock also stated that the story would prove the intelligent nature of the Flood, and "hopefully euthanize the idea that they are just space zombies".<ref name="Hammock 2006"/>
The Flood also feature heavily in [[Greg Bear]]'s trilogy of novels, [[The Forerunner Saga]], which takes place thousands of years before the events of ''Halo: Combat Evolved''. It is revealed in the novel ''Halo: Silentium'' that the Flood are what remains of the Precursors, an ancient race that was said to accelerate the evolution of a species and "shape galaxies". The Forerunners overthrew the Precursors; on the verge of extinction, some Precursors reduced themselves to a biological powder that would regenerate into their past selves. However, time rendered the powder defective, and it became mutagenic, reacting with other living organisms to produce what would eventually mutate into the Flood. The Flood would threaten both ancient humanity and then the Forerunners, who would ultimately build and activate the Halo Array to stop the spread of the Flood.
==Cultural impact== ===Merchandise=== The Flood have been featured in four series of ''Halo'' [[action figure]]s, produced by Joyride Studios. For ''Halo: Combat Evolved'', Joyride produced a Carrier Form and Infection form bundle.<ref>{{cite web|author=Thorson, Thor|date=February 17, 2004|url=http://www.gamespot.com/pc/action/halo/news.html?sid=6089512|title=First Halo 2 action figures appear|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=July 12, 2008}}</ref> ''Halo 2''{{'}}s series contains both a human Combat Form and Infection form (bundled with the Master Chief), which were released after the video game.<ref name="armchair empire review">{{Cite web|author=Simmer, Aaron|date=April 9, 2006|url=http://www.armchairempire.com/action-figures/flood-human-form.htm|title=Flood Human Form (Halo 2)|publisher=The Armchair Empire|accessdate=July 12, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080504185934/http://www.armchairempire.com/action-figures/flood-human-form.htm|archivedate=May 4, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Reviewer Aaron Simmer of Armchair Empire.com expressed the sentiment that Joyride's models could not totally capture the ghoulishness texture and detail of the Flood.<ref name="armchair empire review"/> The action figures for ''[[Halo 3]]'' were produced by [[McFarlane Toys]] and although the first series did not feature the Flood, the third series featured a human Combat Form.<ref>{{cite web|author=Burg, Justin|date=March 26, 2008|url=http://www.xbox360fanboy.com/2008/03/26/halo-3-series-three-mcfarlane-figures-preview/|title=Halo 3 series three McFarlane figures preview|publisher=[[Joystiq|XBox360Fanboy]]|accessdate=April 3, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080330002005/http://www.xbox360fanboy.com/2008/03/26/halo-3-series-three-mcfarlane-figures-preview/|archivedate=March 30, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Critical reception=== <!-- https://kotaku.com/in-defense-of-the-flood-halos-most-hated-enemy-1708166818 --> The surprise appearance of the Flood during ''Halo: Combat Evolved'' was seen as an important plot twist<ref name=GameSpot>{{cite web|author=Fielder, Joe |date=November 9, 2001 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/xbox/action/halo/review.html?page=4 |title=Halo: Combat Evolved for Xbox Review |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=September 4, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929141502/http://www.gamespot.com/xbox/action/halo/review.html?page=4 |archivedate=September 29, 2007 |df= }}</ref> and a scary moment even after repeat playthroughs of the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gameroom.mlgpro.com/view/zyiJ5z9YWvg.html |title=Sci vs. Fi - ''Halo 3'' Documentary |publisher=[[Major League Gaming]] |accessdate=October 5, 2007 |date=October 2, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012175936/http://gameroom.mlgpro.com/view/zyiJ5z9YWvg.html |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |df= }}</ref> [[Gamasutra]], writing about video game plots, gives the example of the Flood not only as an important reversal to the story of ''Halo'', but a textbook example of how games and their stories are made more interesting by twists in the plot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/features/20050727/sutherland_02.shtml|title=What Every Game Developer Needs to Know about Story|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|author=Sutherland, John|date=July 25, 2005|accessdate=December 23, 2007}}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and ''[[Kotaku]]'' credited the appearance of the Flood as an excellent way the game kept players on their toes, forcing them to adjust their strategies; ''Rolling Stone'' called the twist as shocking "as if, several levels into a game of Pac-Man, the dots suddenly began to attack you".<ref name="rolling stone">{{cite journal|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20071012201505/http://rollingstone.com/news/story/16548129/inside_halos_secret_lab/print|url=http://rollingstone.com/news/story/16548129/inside_halos_secret_lab/print|author=Binelli, Mark|archivedate=October 12, 2007|date=October 4, 2007|accessdate=April 15, 2012|title=Inside Halo's Secret Lab|journal=[[Rolling Stone]]|issue=1036|pages=28}}</ref>
Despite the positive acclaim in ''Halo'', the response to the presence of the Flood in ''Halo 2'' and ''Halo 3'' was mixed. A panel of online reviewers noted that the Flood appeared in ''Halo 2'' for no obvious reasons, and were simply described as "aggravating" to play against.<ref name=free>{{cite web|date=2004|url=http://www.teamfremont.com/reviews/Halo2.shtml|title=Team Fremont: Halo 2 review|publisher=TeamFremont|accessdate=September 5, 2007| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050319203907/http://www.teamfremont.com/reviews/Halo2.shtml| archivedate = March 19, 2005}}</ref> Similarly, reviewers including Victor Godinez of ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' felt that the Flood were too derivative of other [[science fiction|sci-fi]] stereotypes, and functioned as "space [[zombie]]s".<ref name=free/><ref>{{cite web|author=Godinez, Victor|date=July 16, 2006|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/ptech/gamereviews2/071806ccdrPTECHhalobook.1d4d3a2.html|title=Review: The Halo Graphic Novel|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|accessdate=September 6, 2007}}</ref> Daniel Weissenberger of Gamecritics.com noted in his review of ''Halo 3'' that even though the Flood looked better than ever, their single strategy of rushing the player proved tedious over time.<ref name="gamecritics review">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamecritics.com/halo-3-review|title=''Halo 3'' Review|author=Weissenberger, Daniel|date=October 1, 2007|accessdate=October 2, 2007|publisher=GameCritics}}</ref> [[GamesRadar]]'s Charlie Barratt listed the Flood as the worst part of ''Halo'', contrasting what he considered fun, vibrant and open levels before the Flood's appearance with confined spaces and predictable enemies.<ref>{{cite web|author=Barratt, Charlie|date=June 16, 2008|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/f/the-top-7-worst-parts-of-best-games/a-200806161050968082/p-2|title=The Top 7... Worst Parts of Best Games|publisher=[[GamesRadar]]|accessdate=March 17, 2009}}</ref> The Flood have been recognized as some of the greatest game villains. ''[[Wizard Magazine]]'' ranked the Flood as the 77th Greatest Villains of all time,<ref name=Wizard>{{cite journal |date=July 2006|title=Top 100 Greatest Villains |journal=[[Wizard Magazine]] |volume=1 |issue= 177}}</ref> Game Daily ranked them 5th of their "Top 25 Enemies of All Time", and ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]'' ranked the Flood the 31st "Most Diabolical Video-Game Villains of All Time".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamedaily.com/articles/galleries/top-25-enemies-of-all-time/?icid=aimDBDL2_link1-b&page=21|publisher=Game Daily|accessdate=August 19, 2008|title=Top 25 Enemies of All Time}}</ref><ref name="PC World">{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.idg.com.au/index.php/id;338891934;pp;1|title=The 47 Most Diabolical Video-Game Villains of All Time|author=Staff|work=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|date=February 4, 2008|accessdate=July 10, 2008}}</ref> ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]'' ranked the Flood in their top ten list of "badass undead".<ref>{{cite journal|author=Sharkey, Steve|date=October 2008|title=EGM's Top Ten Badass Undead: Thriller Night|journal=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]|issue=233|pages=106}}</ref> [[MTV]] considered Flood possession in ''Halo 3'' as a "great gaming moment" of 2007,<ref name="mtv"/> stating that "with the power of the [[Xbox 360]]'s graphics, this reanimation comes to vivid, distressing life, more memorably than it had in the earlier games. Here are the zombies of gaming doing what they do worst. [...] It's grisly and unforgettable."<ref name="mtv">{{cite web|author=Totilo, Stephen|date=December 18, 2007|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1576629/20071217/index.jhtml|title= 'Halo 3,' 'Pac-Man' And More Have Our 10 Great Gaming Moments Of 2007, In GameFile|publisher=[[MTV]]|accessdate=April 2, 2008}}</ref> [[IGN]] listed the Flood as the 45th best video game villain, describing them as one of the most hated video game villains in the history of video games.<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff |date= |url=http://www.ign.com/videogame-villains/45.html |title=The Top 100 Videogame Villains: The Flood |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=August 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100731055332/http://www.ign.com/videogame-villains/45.html |archivedate=July 31, 2010 |df= }}</ref>

'''François de Civille''', seigneur de [[Saint-Mards]] (1537–1610), French soldier and diplomat. The Civille family of [[Rouen]] was of Spanish origin.<ref>Gayle K. Brunelle, 'Immigration, Assimilation and Success: Three Families of Spanish Origin in Sixteenth Century Rouen', ''The Sixteenth Century Journal'', vol. 20, No. 2 (Summer, 1989), pp. 203–220, 214–5.</ref>
==Buried Alive==
François de Civille was a soldier in the [[French Wars of Religion]]. He wrote a memoir describing being found dead, buried, and resuscitated at the siege of [[Rouen]] in 1562. He was shot in the head and fell from the ramparts into the ditch, where workers buried him on 12 October 1562. Civille's groom went to collect the body to bury it properly and found he was still alive. During his recovery, soldiers looking for his younger brother discovered him in bed and threw him out of the window. He landed in a dung heap in the courtyard where he remained senseless in his night clothes for three days until he was found by his cousin. His injuries left him unable to close his mouth without pain. Subsequently, Civille would write "Dead, Buried, Resuscitated" under his signature. Civille wrote a memoir of his 1562 experience and had it printed in 1606. [[Pierre de L'Estoile]] noted its publication in July 1606. In a later addition to the story, it was said that Civille died after falling a third time, falling ill on an icy night while peeping into a neighbour's window.<ref>A. Varillas, ''[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=dFIPAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA256#v=onepage&q&f=false| Histoire de Charles IX]'', vol. 1 (Paris, 1684), 256–7: Ernest Poret Bénigne, Marquis de Blosseville, ''Discours des causes pour lesquelles le Sieur de Civille se dit avoir été mort, enterré et ressuscité'' (Rouen, 1863), XIX, 13–14, 21.</ref>
==Diplomat and Refugee== As a diplomat he worked for Françoise de Bourbon, [[Duchess of Bouillon]] and was an informant for [[Francis Walsingham]], reporting on English visitors at Rouen, and declared that he was as sure and constant in Walsingham's service 'as a diamond is hard'.<ref>A. Aubry, ''La Normandie à l'étranger: documents inédits relatifs à l'histoire de Normandie'' (Paris, 1873), 243.</ref> He sent gifts of dried fruit, apples and pears, to [[Ursula St Barbe]] and [[Lettice Knollys]], the wives of Walsingham and [[Robert Dudley, 1st Earl of Leicester]]. He came to London and met [[Elizabeth I]] in 1584 and 1588.<ref>E.J.B. Allen, ''Post and Courier Service in the Diplomacy of Early Modern Europe'' (Hague, 1972), 34–5, 56: ''Calendar State Papers Foreign Elizabeth'', vol. 19, p.524</ref> He and his wife, Jehanne du Mouchet, and family came to [[Rye, East Sussex|Rye]] in July 1585 and were listed as Protestant refugees in London in January 1586.<ref>''Calendar State Papers London Foreign Elizabeth'', vol. 20 (London, 1921), 293.</ref> [[File:Elizabeth I of England holding an olive branch.jpg|thumb|Portrait of Elizabeth I of England said to have been a gift to François de Civille in 1588.]] In 1588, Elizabeth gave him a jewel and her portrait, according to an inscription on a painting belonging to his descendants.<ref>Ernest Poret Blosseville, ''Discours des causes pour lesquelles le sieur de Civille'' (Rouen, 1863), p.XII: [http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/Lot/english-school-circa-1585-1590-portrait-of-queen-5701777-details.aspx| Details of the portrait of Elizabeth, Christie's London 2 July 2013, no. 23.]</ref> Leaving his wife in London, he travelled to Edinburgh in March 1589 to raise an army of 3000 soldiers for [[Henri IV of France |Henri of Navarre]] and work on the unsuccessful negotiations for the marriage of [[James VI of Scotland]] to [[Catherine de Bourbon]] sister of Henri of Navarre. James was advised of Civille's mission by Henri's letter of 23 December 1588. James married [[Anne of Denmark]] instead.<ref>A. Cameron, ''Warrender Papers'', vol. 2 (Edinburgh, 1932), 91–2, 107–8: ''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 10 (Edinburgh, 1936), 7: ''Calendar State Papers Foreign Elizabeth'' vol. 23, (London, 1950), 10: Ernest Poret Blosseville, (Rouen, 1863), p.XIII.</ref> Civille mentioned in a letter from [[East Wemyss|Wemyss]] that the [[Henry Hastings, 3rd Earl of Huntingdon|Earl of Huntingdon]] was his 'old and gracious master'. Civille left Scotland in September 1589 accompanied by [[James Colville, 1st Lord Colville of Culross|Sir James Colville of Easter Wemyss]].<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 10 (Edinburgh, 1936), 141, 154.</ref>
In January 1598 Henri IV ordered Civille as "Commissaire Ordinaire des Guerres" to take command of troops at [[Saumur]].<ref>Jules Berger de Xivray, ''Recueil des lettres missives de Henri IV'' vol. 4 (Paris, 1848). 895-6.</ref>
== Works == * ''Discours des causes pour lesquelles le sieur de Civille, gentilhomme de Normandie, se dit avoir esté mort, enterré et ressuscité'' (1606), [https://archive.org/stream/discoursdescause00civi#page/n15/mode/2up| Edited by Ernest Poret Blosseville, (Rouen, 1863)]. * Some of Civille's letters are printed in A. Aubry, ''[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gGT-fApADmcC&pg=PA238#v=onepage&q&f=false| La Normandie à l'étranger: documents inédits relatifs à l'histoire de Normandie, tirés des archives étrangères XVIe et XVIIe siècles]'' (Paris, 1873), 238–254.

{{Infobox film | name = Frozen | image = Frozen Poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Adam Green (filmmaker)|Adam Green]] | producer = Peter Block
Cory Neal | writer = Adam Green | starring = [[Emma Bell]]
[[Shawn Ashmore]]
[[Kevin Zegers]] | music = Andy Garfield | cinematography = [[Will Barratt]] | editing = Ed Marx | studio = A Bigger Boat
ArieScope Pictures | distributor = [[Anchor Bay Films]] | released = {{Film date|2010|1|24|[[26th Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]]|2010|2|5|United States}} | runtime = 93 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $3.1 million{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=frozen.htm |title=Frozen (2010) |work=Box Office Mojo |date=2010-04-01 |accessdate=2010-08-26}} }} '''''Frozen''''' is a 2010 American [[thriller film|thriller]]-[[drama film]] written and directed by [[Adam Green (filmmaker)|Adam Green]] and starring [[Emma Bell]], [[Shawn Ashmore]] and [[Kevin Zegers]]. ==Plot== Childhood friends Dan Walker and Joe Lynch, along with Dan's girlfriend Parker O'Neil, spend a Sunday afternoon at a New England ski resort on Mount Holliston. They are eager to take one last run down the mountain before they go home; however, the ski resort decides to close early because a storm is moving in. The friends convince the ski lift attendant to let them on one last time. Before the group gets all the way to the top, the attendant is called into the boss's office and is replaced by a co-worker. As he leaves, he tells the co-worker that there are only three skiers left. Another set of three skiers comes down the mountain. When he sees them, he shuts down the ski lift, stranding the three friends in their ski lift chair far above the ground. They take it as a joke, but the ski resort's lights are then turned off, leaving the three friends in fear and shock. Parker knows the ski slopes have closed for the week. Dan feels he has no choice but to jump from the ski lift chair and get help, as they will not survive up there in the bitter cold until Friday. After discussing the danger, Dan decides to jump off the lift. Upon hitting the ground, he suffers a [[compound fracture]] on both of his legs. Soon, his screams and the scent of blood attracts a pack of wolves. Joe, now fearing for Dan's safety, decides to try to get to the ground by traversing the suspension cable between the lifts and [[steel]] support tower. However, as wolves close in on Dan, he returns to the chair and holds Parker as Dan is brutally torn apart by the wolves. In the morning, Parker awakes with her hand frozen on the bar, which she grabbed during her sleep. She is also suffering severe [[frostbite]]. Joe discusses his previous life experiences with her, before attempting to traverse the ski lift cable, and onto a support pole on the other side. By doing this, he also causes the chair Parker is sitting in to dangerously loosen from the cable. After scaring off a pair of wolves by using a ski pole, he slides down the mountain on Parker's snowboard, planning to return with help. The wolves give chase after him. Joe never returns and Parker spends the night alone on the loose cable. The next day, Parker begins to climb out of the lift, but the screw comes loose and causes the lift to fall. Blocked by a cable, the lift is hanging a few meters above the ground. Parker jumps and then the lift lands on her ankle. Injured, she begins to slide and crawl down the mountain. She encounters the wolves feasting on Joe's mutilated corpse. Too occupied with Joe's corpse, they ignore her as she continues down, eventually crawling to a nearby road. The first car that passes doesn't see her but soon a minivan appears and the driver, seeing her outstretched body lying in the snow along the side of the road, stops to assist her. The film ends with the driver saying they are going to a nearby hospital, followed by Parker closing her eyes. ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Emma Bell]] as Parker O'Neil * [[Shawn Ashmore]] as Joe Lynch, Dan's Best Friend * [[Kevin Zegers]] as Dan Walker, Parker's Boyfriend and Joe's Best Friend * [[Rileah Vanderbilt]] as Shannon * Ed Ackerman as Jason * Adam Johnson as Rifkin * [[Chris York|Christopher York]] as Ryan * [[Kane Hodder]] as Cody * [[Will Barratt]] as Sullivan * [[Adam Green (filmmaker)|Adam Green]] as Guy on Chairlift #1 * [[Joe Lynch (director)|Joe Lynch]] as Guy on Chairlift #2 * Peder Melhuse as Driver * [[Dee Snider#Personal life|Cody Blue Snider]] as [[Twisted Sister]] fan in cafeteria {{div col end}} ==Production== ''Frozen'' was filmed at [[Snowbasin]] near [[Ogden, Utah]], in February 2009{{cite web | url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/35118/official-frozen-website-opens-its-doors|title=Official Frozen Website Opens its Doors|last=Barton|first=Steve|work=[[Dread Central]]|date=2009-12-28|accessdate=2010-08-26}} and distributed by [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18348|title=Sundance '10: First Hi-Res Look at Adam Green Chiller 'Frozen'|last=Miska|first=Brad|work=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|date=2009-12-10|accessdate=2010-08-26}} ==Release== The film premiered at the 2010 [[Sundance Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18393 |title=Sundance '10: Low Quality Look at the Official One Sheet for 'Frozen'|last=Miska|first=Brad|work=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|date=2009-12-15|accessdate=2010-08-26}} It was released in North American theaters on February 5, 2010,{{cite web|last=Barton|first=Steve|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/34913/first-stills-adam-greens-frozen|title=First Stills from Adam Green's ''Frozen''|work=[[Dread Central]]|date=2009-12-10|accessdate=2010-08-26}} with distribution from Anchor Bay Films.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18513|title=New 'Season of the Witch' Stills, 'Frozen' Website Launch|last=Miska|first=Brad|work=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|date=2009-12-27|accessdate=2010-08-26}} While playing at Sundance, the film caused quite a stir with numerous faintings reported from audience members that could not handle the tension of the film. One such fainting happened at the Tower Theater in Salt Lake City.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/35610/things-get-chilling-sundance-frozen-screenings |title=EXCL: Things Get Chilling at Sundance ''Frozen'' Screenings|last=Barton|first=Steve|work=[[Dread Central]]|date=2010-01-29|accessdate=2010-08-26}} ''Frozen'' also opened the Glasgow FrightFest.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/35641/exclusive-image-and-premiere-news-2001-maniacs-field-screams-and-frozen-invade-scotland|title=Exclusive Image and Premiere News: 2001 Maniacs: ''Field of Screams'' and ''Frozen'' Invade Scotland|last=Barton|first=Steve|work=[[Dread Central]]|date=2010-02-01|accessdate=2010-08-26}} On February 5, the film had multiple screens in areas in Boston, New York, Los Angeles,{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18873|title=Update: First Cities Announced for Adam Green's 'Frozen'|last=Miska|first=Brad|work=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|date=2010-01-28|accessdate=2010-08-26}} Salt Lake City, Dallas, Denver, Philadelphia, Minneapolis and Chicago.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/35580/find-out-where-you-can-get-frozen |title=Find Out Where You Can Get Frozen|last=Barton|first=Steve|work=[[Dread Central]]|date=2010-01-28|accessdate=2010-08-26}} The film premiered on February 5, 2010 with the entire cast and crew at Mann Chinese 6 on Hollywood Blvd.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/35689/see-frozen-this-friday-and-saturday-la-with-cast-and-crew|title=See Frozen This Friday and Saturday in LA With the Cast and the Crew|last=Barton|first=Steve|work=[[Dread Central]]|date=2010-02-03|accessdate=2010-08-26}} ''Frozen'' was released in Malaysia on June 24, 2010. ===Box office=== ''Frozen'' opened to a first weekend box office of $131,395. It underperformed the following weeks. Internationally, the film earned over $2.4 million, bringing its total gross receipts to slightly less than $2.7 million. At its widest domestic release, it screened in 106 theaters. ===Home media=== The film was released on a single disc [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] on September 28, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38376/get-frozen-september|title=Get Frozen this September!|last=Barton|first=Steve|work=[[Dread Central]]|date=2010-07-06|accessdate=2010-08-26}} Bonus features include an [[audio commentary]] with writer/director Adam Green and the leads Shawn Ashmore, Kevin Zegers and Emma Bell; the documentaries "Catching Frostbite: The Origins of ''Frozen''", "Three Below Zero", "Shooting Through It" and "Beating the Mountain: Surviving ''Frozen''"; [[deleted scene]]s; and the [[Film trailer|official theatrical trailer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38439/exclusive-early-word-frozen-dvd-and-blu-ray-specs|title=Exclusive Early Word on Frozen DVD and Blu-Ray Specs|last=Barton|first=Steve|work=[[Dread Central]]|date=2010-07-09|accessdate=2010-08-26}} The Blu-ray features an exclusive commentary from Adam Green, cinematographer Will Barratt, and editor Ed Marx.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38552/blu-ray-and-dvd-art-adam-greens-frozen|title=Blu-ray and DVD Art: Adam Green's ''Frozen''|last=Barton|first=Steve|work=[[Dread Central]]|date=2010-07-15|accessdate=2010-08-26}} ===Soundtrack=== A soundtrack album consisting of the film's complete score, composed by Andy Garfield was released by 2M1 Records Group in January 2011. It is available in a limited pressed run of 500 copies signed by Garfield and [[Adam Green (filmmaker)|Adam Green]]. The album was produced by George Fox. Additionally, it has been released on [[iTunes]] and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] as a [[Music download|download]]. ==Reception== ===Critical=== [[Rotten Tomatoes]], a [[review aggregator]], reports that 62% of 91 surveyed critics gave it a positive review, and the average rating was 5.8/10; the site's consensus is: "Writer/director Adam Green has the beginnings of an inventive, frightening yarn in ''Frozen'', but neither the script nor the cast are quite strong enough to truly do it justice."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/10012051-frozen|title=Frozen|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=2014-01-02}} Critic [[Richard Roeper]] called the film "an entertaining, suspense-filled, sometimes wonderfully grotesque little scarefest",{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1N1-12DB0F1256971C90.html|title=Three friends face a final deep freeze|last=Roeper|first=Richard|authorlink=Richard Roeper|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=2010-02-05|accessdate=2014-01-02}} though ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' commented that it "is not written, directed, or acted well enough to be a first-rate thriller".{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/frozen-film-review-29199|title=Frozen -- Film Review|last=Greenberg|first=James|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=2010-10-14|accessdate=2014-01-02}} Jeannette Catsoulis of ''[[The New York Times]]'' made it a NYT Critics' Pick and wrote, "A minimalist setup delivers maximum fright in ''Frozen'', a nifty little chiller that balances its cold terrain with an unexpectedly warm heart."{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/05/movies/05frozen.html?partner=Rotten%2520Tomatoes&ei=5083&_r=0|title=A Nightmare on a Ski Lift|last=Catsoulis|first=Jeannette|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2010-02-04|accessdate=2014-01-02}} Peter Debruge of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' wrote, "Don’t be surprised if the movie’s most wince-inducing moments come not from the "disturbing images" (as the MPAA describes the sight of a leg bone sticking six inches out of one character's ski pants) but rather of the bad acting and worse dialogue."{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2010/film/reviews/frozen-1117942010/|title=Review: 'Frozen'|last=Debruge|first=Peter|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=2010-01-28|accessdate=2014-01-02}} ===Awards=== It was nominated for a [[Saturn Award for Best Horror Film]], but lost to ''[[Drag Me to Hell]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/36020/2010-saturn-award-nominees-announced|title=2010 Saturn Award Nominees Announced|last=Moore|first=Debi|work=[[Dread In [[artificial intelligence]], especially [[computer vision]] and [[artificial neural network]]s, a '''hard sigmoid''' is non-[[smoothness|smooth]] function used in place of a [[sigmoid function]]. These retain the basic shape of a sigmoid, rising from 0 to 1, but using simpler functions, especially [[piecewise linear function]]s or [[piecewise constant function]]s. These are preferred where speed of computation is more important than precision. == Examples == The most extreme examples are the [[sign function]] or [[Heaviside step function]], which go from −1 to 1 or 0 to 1 (which to use depends on normalization) at 0.Curves and Surfaces in Computer Vision and Graphics, Volume 1610, SPIE, 1992, [https://books.google.com/books?id=9fpRAQAAIAAJ&q=%22hard+sigmoid%22 p. 301] Other examples include the [[Theano (software)|Theano]] library, which provides two approximations: ultra_fast_sigmoid, which is a multi-part piecewise linear approximation and hard_sigmoid, which is a 3-part piecewise linear approximation (output 0, line with slope 5, output 1).[http://deeplearning.net/software/theano/library/tensor/nnet/nnet.html nnet – Ops for neural networks] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Artificial neural networks]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Hossein Sami'i | image = Adib al-Saltaneh.png | caption = Hossein Sami'i, 1930s | birth_name = Hossein ibn Hassan Sami'i Gilani | birth_date = 1876 | birth_place = [[Rasht]] | death_date = 5 February 1954 | death_place = [[Tehran]] | nationality = Iranian | other_names = Adib al-Saltaneh | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} [[Mirza]] '''Hossein''' [[Khan (title)|Khan]] '''Sami'i''' ({{lang-fa|حسین سمیعی}}) also known by his court title of '''Adib al Saltaneh'''({{lang-fa|ادیب السلطنه}}){{Cite book |title=القاب رجال دورهٔ قاجاریه |last=Soleimani |first=Karim |date=2000 |publisher=Nashre Ney |isbn=9643124843 |location=Tehran |pages=28–29 |trans-title=Qajar period titles of men}} (1876 - 5 February 1954) was an Iranian writer, poet, diplomat and politician who had shifted in many positions in both [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar]] and [[Pahlavi dynasty|Pahlavi]] governments. He worked first in the Foreign Ministry and then as head of the Office of Neighboring Governments. Entered the Ministry of the Interior in 1910 and was deputy of Rasht in the [[National Consultative Assembly]] 1914-1918.{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/in.ernet.dli.2015.504577/2015.504577.Shaknowran-Nami-1#page/n323/mode/2up |title=سخنوران نامی ایران در تاریخ معاصر |last=Eshaq |first=Mohammad |publisher=Tolo' and Sirus |year=1984 |edition=1 |pages=330–343 |language=Persian |trans-title=Famous authors of Iran the in contemporary history |access-date=8 December 2017}} == Biography == Hossein ibn Hassan Sami'i Gilani, Born in 1876 in [[Rash]]t into a notable family. Spent his childhood in Tehran and Kermanshah and studied Arabic and literary sciences at Kermanshah, Taught by Abu al-Foqara' al-Isfahani and Mirza Salik al-Kermanshahi. He began writing poetry from the age of eleven by his [[pen name]] of ''[[Ata (name)|‘Aṭā]]''. He returned to Tehran in 1893 and worked in the Foreign Ministry in the [[Qajar dynasty|Qajari court]] during the reign of [[Muzaffar al-Din Shah|Muzaffar al-Din]]. Moved to the Ministry of Interior after the constitutional revolution in 1907, Elected as a deputy for Rasht in the third session of the [[National Consultative Assembly]] in 1914. Moved between the ministries of Interior and "General Benefits" later, Then he was appointed governor of Tehran.
He wrote few books, taught Political science and appointed as president of the Iranian Literary Academy. He also took over the head of the scout organization. In 1935 after the establishment of the First Academy of Sciences, he was elected its member.
In 1940, he was promoted to Iran's Ambassador to Afghanistan, remained in office for almost two years and then returned to the presidency of the Academy. He died in 5 February 1953 and buried in the [[Ibn Babawayh Cemetery]], south of [[Tehran]]. == His works == * ''Rules of writing'' * ''Memories of immigration travel'' * ''Poetry [[Diwan (poetry)|Diwan]]'' * ''The spirit of speech'' * ''Persian grammar'' * ''Human desires'' * ''Sisters'' * ''Al-Siyasah'': Arabic. He also translated ''The history of Afghanistan'' by Jamal al-Din al-Afghani from Arabic to Persian. == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Sami'i, Hossein}} [[Category:1876 births]] [[Category:1953 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Iranian writers]] [[Category:20th-century Iranian poets]] [[Category:Iranian politicians]] [[Category:Iranian diplomats]] [[Category:Deaths in Tehran]] [[Category:Members of the National Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:Iranian male writers]] [[Category:Government ministers of Iran]] [[Category:People from Rasht]] [[Category:Deputies of Rasht for National Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Iran to Afghanistan]] [[Category:20th-century male writers]]
